chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Hypercalcaemia - known malignancy
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with hypercalcaemia of known malignancy.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with hypercalcaemia due to known malignancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person has a known malignancy felt to be the underlying cause of hypercalcaemia:

  • Discuss with the person and/or carers whether management of hypercalcaemia is appropriate, depending on clinical judgement.
    • Treatment of hypercalcaemia may not be appropriate if the person is receiving palliative care and is felt to be approaching the end of life. See the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues for more information.
  • If the person has severe hypercalcaemia or severe symptoms:
    • Offer emergency hospital admission for further specialist assessment and management such as intravenous fluids and intravenous bisphosphonate therapy (pamidronate or zoledronate), depending on clinical judgement and the person's wishes.
    • Liaise with the person's oncologist or palliative care specialist if there is any uncertainty about ongoing management. Offer referral to a palliative care specialist for additional support and management if appropriate. See the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues for more information.
  • If the person is asymptomatic or has minimal symptoms, with mild or moderate hypercalcaemia:
    • Liaise with the person's oncologist or palliative care specialist if there is any uncertainty about ongoing management.
    • Arrange monitoring and follow-up in primary care, as appropriate. See the Scenario on Follow-up in primary care for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of a person with known malignancy are based on the Society for Endocrinology guideline Emergency management of acute hypercalcaemia in adult patients [Walsh, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles on hypercalcaemia [Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Turner, 2017], on parathyroid disorders [Michels, 2013], on hypercalcaemia of malignancy [Seccareccia, 2010; Clines, 2011; Zagzag, 2018], and in a palliative care textbook A guide to symptom relief in palliative care [Regnard, 2010].

  • The recommendation to discuss whether management of hypercalcaemia is appropriate is based on the fact that malignancy-associated hypercalcaemia is a poor prognostic indicator, and correction of hypercalcaemia does not improve survival [Seccareccia, 2010; Zagzag, 2018]. It is also based on the expert opinion of a previous external reviewer of this CKS topic, and is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendation to arrange emergency admission if the person has severe hypercalcaemia or severe symptoms is based on the fact this is a potential oncological emergency, which may benefit from intravenous hydration and possible intravenous bisphosphonate therapy, to urgently correct hypercalcaemia, reduce potentially distressing symptoms, and reduce the risk of life-threatening complications [Regnard, 2010; Clines, 2011; Michels, 2013; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Walsh, 2016; Turner, 2017].
    • People with malignancy-associated hypercalcaemia are more likely to be symptomatic, as the likelihood of symptoms is related to the rate of onset of hypercalcaemia which is typically severe and of rapid-onset [Clines, 2011; Zagzag, 2018].
    • Intravenous fluid therapy and correction of hypovolaemia may also improve renal function and help urinary excretion of calcium [Zagzag, 2018].
    • Bisphosphonate therapy has potential additional benefits of reducing bone pain and the risk of pathological fractures [Seccareccia, 2010].
  • The recommendation to liaise with the person's oncologist or palliative care specialist if there is any uncertainty about ongoing management is based on expert opinion in review articles that note that treatment of the underlying malignancy may improve hypercalcaemia [Minisola, 2015; Zagzag, 2018].
  • The recommendation to offer referral to a palliative care specialist is based on expert opinion in a review article [Zagzag, 2018], and is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
